file_name: .What is an obituary?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What is an obituary?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What is an obituary?
answer_text:
An obituary is a written account or summary of one's life to inform community members of their passing, 

An obituary is a written account or summary of one's life to inform community members of their passing. It is an opportunity to show the world who this person was and why their life mattered. Obituaries are often the last message written about a loved one, shedding light on the best parts of their life and highlighting how amazing they were.

file_name: .How should anecdotes in a eulogy be used?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/How should anecdotes in a eulogy be used?.md
subject: communication
question_text: How should anecdotes in a eulogy be used?
answer_text:
Anecdotes should be personal and make a bigger point about the person's character.

For example, telling a story about a time the deceased showed kindness to an animal could illustrate their compassion for the underdog.

file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/How should a eulogy reflect the deceased?.md
subject: communication
question_text: How should a eulogy reflect the deceased?
answer_text:
It should reflect the emotions, lessons, and memories that the deceased would want people to feel and acknowledge.

A eulogy should reflect the emotions, lessons, and memories that the deceased would want people to feel and acknowledge. It can highlight favorite stories, jokes, travels, and special moments shared with the deceased.

subject: communication
question_text: How can a speaker infuse qualities of their connection with the loved one into the eulogy's introduction?
answer_text:
By joking about being the favorite grandchild or sharing personal anecdotes about the loved one.

A speaker can infuse qualities of their connection with the loved one into the eulogy's introduction by joking about being the favorite grandchild, sharing personal anecdotes about the loved one, or mentioning unique aspects of their relationship.

file_name: .What should be avoided when delivering a eulogy?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/What should be avoided when delivering a eulogy?.md
subject: communication
question_text: What should be avoided when delivering a eulogy?
answer_text:
Avoid embarrassing stories or revelations that would tarnish others' memories of the deceased. Keep private conversations and secrets between you and the deceased.

When delivering a eulogy, it is important to avoid stories that would be embarrassing to the deceased or that would tarnish others’ memories of them. Keep private conversations and secrets between you and the deceased. A eulogy is not the time to deliver earth-shattering news or embarrassing revelations about the deceased’s past.

A value used for a parameter if no argument is provided in the function call

question_text: Francois Poulain De La Barre was remembered for his 1673 book "On the equality of the Two Sexes". What is his main argument?
answer_text:
The Mind has no sex

Since what we are is mind, then men and women are fundamentally the same since we both have mind.

P1 - Humanity is defined by the rational soul, which exists independent of the body.
P2 - Biological sex pertains to the body.
C - So, humanity is not different depending on sex.

question_text: What is Descartes stance on animals? How does he view them?
answer_text:
As complex machinery, meaning we don't need to imagine an animal has Soul/Mind in order to move.

Background: Descartes is a leading authority at his time of how bodies work. He is discovering all the ways bodiesreally do work like very complex machines. Things have a purpose. Most of the activity of our bodies is NOTdictated by reason, but happens automatically. He sees how muscles work, how lungs work, how digestion works -all like purpose-built Machines

file_name: .Among the following, which is the best formulation of Descartes' argument regarding sensory information the "First Meditation".md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Among the following, which is the best formulation of Descartes' argument regarding sensory information the "First Meditation".md
subject: philosophy
related: [[Meditations of First Philosophy - First Meditation - Rene Descartes]]
question_text:
Among the following, which is the best formulation of Descartes' argument regarding sensory information the "First Meditation"

A. Our senses have fooled us on multiple occasions. There is no way to tell that they are not fooling us now. So, we should exercise some level of skepticism regarding empirical knowledge and take it as only probable. 

B. Our senses have fooled us on multiple occasions. There is no way to tell that they are not fooling us now. So, we should take a methodological position of total skepticism and reject all sensory information as false 

C. Our senses have fooled us on multiple occasions. For example, we have taken dreams to be true. Thus, there are very good reasons to think that we are living in some form of virtual reality right now.
answer_text: B

file_name: .In the Meditations, . . .which is the best formulation of the justification he gives for his decision?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/In the Meditations, . . .which is the best formulation of the justification he gives for his decision?.md
subject: philosophy
question_text:
In the Meditations, René Descartes decides to reject as false “all the opinions he has formerly accepted”, even if he does not know for sure that they are indeed false. Among the following,which is the best formulation of the justification he gives for his decision? 

A. Descartes is investigating whether there is any instance of knowledge that is absolutely certain. Since he recognizes that he has accepted all his current opinions by relying on unreliable sources, these opinions ought to be taken as false in the context of this particular investigation. 

B. Descartes is investigating whether there is any instance of knowledge that is absolutely certain. Looking at each of his opinions’ content, he has found out that all of them are false.

C. Descartes is looking to provide a true foundation for Modern science. Since he recognizes that he has accepted a lot of his opinions on the basis of Aristotle’s views,these opinions ought to be taken as false because they could conflict with the new science. 

D. Descartes is looking to provide a true foundation for Modern science. Since he takes knowledge to come from the impressions we get from our sensations and reflections, he decides to start with a blank slate.
answer_text: A

file_name: .Define Gender Essentialism.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Define Gender Essentialism.md
subject: philosophy
question_text: Define Gender Essentialism
answer_text:
The attribution of a fixed essence to each gender. Men and Women's essence is assumed to be universal for all members of the kind.

Example:
Complementarianism: a (mostly) theological view, especially in Abrahamic religions, that Women and Men have different but complementary natures and, thus, different roles and responsibilities.

Many people want to argue there is absolutely (metaphysically speaking) NO essential, No necessary characteristic of any gender. The concepts are completely socially constructed and changing over time and space.

file_name: .Why is the phrase "Cogito, ergo sum" so important to Descartes?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Why is the phrase "Cogito, ergo sum" so important to Descartes?.md
subject: philosophy
question_text:
Why is the phrase "Cogito, ergo sum" so important to Descartes? 

A. It means “The sum of everything is thought” - and it expresses Descartes’ idea that all reality is immaterial ideas 

B. It means “I think, therefore I am” - and it expresses Descartes’ idea that only the thinking,philosophical life is worth living.

C. It means “Ergonomic Cognition” - and it was the belief that thinking is done best in a comfortable setting.

D. It means “I think, therefore I am” - and it was the first thing Descartes found that absolutely could not be doubted.
answer_text: D

file_name: .Define the view of Strategic Essentialism, in regards to Gender Essentialism.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Define the view of Strategic Essentialism, in regards to Gender Essentialism.md
subject: philosophy
question_text: Define the view of Strategic Essentialism, in regards to Gender Essentialism
answer_text:
The view that a group is NOT metaphysically distinct, and yet there are strategic social reasons for a marginalized group to stress distinctness and shared identity in a struggle for equal rights. 

Example: Someone might not think there is one kind of essence that defines a Woman, or a Queer person, or an Indigenous Person, and yet it can be politically important to stress distinctiveness as a group to (1) foster political unity and (2) more clearly communicate the nature of their marginalization.

file_name: .Define the view of Essentialism?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Define the view of Essentialism?.md
subject: philosophy
question_text: Define the view of Essentialism?
answer_text:
The view that objects have a set of attributes that are necessary to their identity. 

Further:
It’s easy to see how Rationalism lends itself to Essentialism. Plato and Descartes are the bestexamples. If we can know different KINDS of things by reason alone, then those differences in KIND are very rigid, perhaps even eternal truths. Like, a triangle is forever and always a different kind of thing than a square. A Mind is forever and always essentially different than a body.But Empiricists can be essentialists too. Carl Linnaeus, father of biological taxonomy, was a pretty firm essentialist. Now, his strict essentialism (some argue) cannot be empirically defended.That doesn’t stop it from remaining the foundational metaphysical presumption in centuries ofempirical studies. (lol)But even a less strict, empiricist essentialism might hope that human categories (our every day divisions and groupings of the world around us) might express something true about reality. They might still “Carve nature at its joints.” (from Plato’s Phaedrus, but a surviving aspiration of empiricism)

question_text:
Check out the following class definition:

class Dog:
    species = "Canis familaris"
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

Which of the following statements about the Dog class are true?
1. To create new instances of Dog, you have to manually pass a value to the self parameter
2. Instantiating this class raise a TypeError every time
3. The .species attribute has the same value for every class instance
4. To create new instances of Dog, you have to manually pass values to the name and age parameters
answer_text:
3 & 4 are true

"The class attribute .species already has an initial value, which will be the same for every instance of this class.

To instantiate objects of this Dog class, you need to provide values for the name and age parameters. If you don’t, then Python raises a TypeError.

However, you don’t need to provide a value for the self parameter, because when you instantiate a Dog object, Python creates a new instance and passes it to the first parameter of .__init__()."

file_name: .Fill in the blank, In Python, an object is considered `___________` if it can be altered dynamically..md

subject: computer_science
question_text: Fill in the blank, In Python, an object is considered `___________` if it can be altered dynamically.
answer_text:
mutable

"In Python, an object is considered mutable you can alter it dynamically.

This means that you can change its state or contents at runtime. Lists and dictionaries are examples of mutable objects.

On the other hand, strings and tuples are examples of immutable objects, which means that you can’t change their state or content after creating them.

This is an important concept to understand when working with different types of data in Python. For example, when you create a custom class, instances of that class are mutable by default. This means that you can change their attributes dynamically."

class Emp():

        self.name = name

subject: computer_science
question_text: What's the difference between class attributes and instance attributes in Python?
answer_text:
Class attributes have the same value for all instances, but instance attributes can have a different value for each instance.

Explanation:
"Class attributes in Python are attributes that have the same value for all instances of a class. You must always assign them an initial value. When an instance of the class is created, class attributes are automatically created and assigned to their initial values.Instance attributes, on the other hand, are attributes whose value is specific to a particular instance of the class. They’re usually created and assigned in the .__init__() method."

question_text: In Python,__________ is a blueprint for how something should be defined, but it doesn’t contain any data. On the other hand, _________ is an object built from a class, and it contains real data.
answer_text:
a class
an instance 

A class is a blueprint for how something should be defined. It doesn’t actually contain any data. For example, a Dog class may specify that a name and an age are necessary for defining a dog, but it doesn’t contain the name or age of any specific dog.

On the other hand, an instance is an object that’s built from a class and contains real data. An instance of a Dog class isn’t a blueprint anymore. It’s an actual dog with a name, like Frieda, who’s four years old.
